issue.title: Unable to find version '2.6.4' of package 'NUnit'.

milestone.title: Closed Without Action
milestone.description: This milestone contains closed issues where no action was taken. This includes questions, issues that could not be reproduced, rejected ideas, invalid issues, etc.

issue.body:
as of 
commit f23c6a0c27c37472e12dfc6703998fbab7ed6505
Date:   2015-08-16T14:27:06-07:00

```
    # nuget restore nunit.linux.sln
    Unable to find version '1.1.10' of package 'Microsoft.Bcl'.
    Unable to find version '1.0.168' of package 'Microsoft.Bcl.Async'.
    Unable to find version '1.0.21' of package 'Microsoft.Bcl.Build'.
    Unable to find version '2.6.4' of package 'NUnit'.
```

Of course it can't find NUnit in local repository, because I am just building it for the first time

Isn't it better to add project dependency instead of package dependency?

rename.to: build and build.cmd scripts invoke nuget.exe improperly

body:
@chris-smith-zocdoc Please take this comment as the description of the issue, rather than the original above. The original gives useful general info but doesn't actually say what the problem is.

When you fixed issue #125, you modified both scripts to include the restore. The primary issue is that you are invoking nuget.exe, a managed program, without the mono prefix. Apparently, the OS we run under on travis implements binfmt to support .NET execution, so the prefix is not needed. Our general policy, in keeping with the mono distribution guidelines is to use the prefix all the time. This is a surprise to me, because I didn't know that nuget.exe is a managed program.

The build script should always use 'mono'.

The build.cmd script could use 'mono' when you are using xbuild but probably doesn't have to.

One added question: Did you consider leaving the build scripts alone and putting the restore into NUnit.proj? This would mean, of course, that we would have to use NUnit.proj for all our batch builds, but we can certainly do that if necessary.

I'm assigning this back to you since you worked on the initial fix. Let me know if it's a duplicate of the other one I assigned.

"Please comment on #778 regarding what error checking you would like to see in which of our scripts. "

if there is an error, the script should stop. If you throw away the information - this creates various additional risks (of nonupdated packages with malicious code and so on).

It shouln't start building and hope that another error occurs and display the information which you thrown away before.

for bash see http://www.davidpashley.com/articles/writing-robust-shell-scripts/#idm5413512
if [ "$?"-ne 0]; then echo "command failed"; exit 1; fi

Fair enough. We have been treating these scripts as only used by us at the command line and they only wrapped a single command up to now. But they may be used by other scripts, as you point out.

@chris-smith-zocdoc If you retain the call to nuget in the script, we should check the return code. I think you work on linux, right? If not, you can re-assign it to me.

I won't have time for a couple of days so I assigned it back to you @CharliePoole 

I've tested on linux but I don't primarily work there
OK. I'll take care of it.
